title: What to Know About Ellen DeGeneres' Life in England
description: Ellen DeGeneres and wife Portia de Rossi relocated to England in 2024, embracing countryside living with their pets and simpler lifestyle
content:
Ellen DeGeneres and her wife, Portia de Rossi, moved across the pond where they are admittedly thriving.

DeGeneres and de Rossi, who have been married since 2008, relocated from Los Angeles to England in fall 2024.

“It’s absolutely beautiful. We’re just not used to seeing this kind of beauty,” DeGeneres said during a talk with broadcaster Richard Bacon in July 2025. “The villages and the towns and the architecture — everything you see is charming and it’s just a simpler way of life.”

She added, “It’s clean. Everything here is just better, the way animals are treated, people are polite. I just love it here.”

DeGeneres and de Rossi even brought their menagerie of pets, including a stable of horses, to the United Kingdom.

Keep scrolling to learn more about DeGeneres’ quiet life in England:

DeGeneres said during her BBC conversation that she and the Arrested Development alum initially purchased acreage in the Cotswolds to use as a “part-time house.” They made their move permanent after Donald Trump won the presidential election in November 2024.

“We got here the day before the election and woke up to lots of texts from our friends with crying emojis, and I was like, ‘He got in,’” the comedian recalled. “And we’re like, ‘We’re staying here.’”

Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi Live in the Countryside

The former Ellen DeGeneres Show host often shares glimpses of the couple’s new abode via social media, showing off the open-concept floor plan with cozy decor such as flannel blankets, leather armchairs and a copper-colored striped area rug.

They ultimately listed the 43-acre property, named Kitesbridge Farm, for sale in July 2025.

“When we decided to live here full-time, we knew that Portia couldn’t live without her horses,” DeGeneres told The Wall Street Journal in a statement. “We needed a home that had a horse facility and pastures for them.”

A source told Us in August 2025 that DeGeneres had been spending the bulk of her time farming, gardening and taking care of her pet animals.

“Those close to her have never seen her happier,” the insider added.

After DeGeneres and de Rossi moved to England, a source exclusively told Us Weekly that they have been regular guests at the exclusive Soho Farmhouse.

“She was dressed in a country casual way,” the insider said in November 2024. “She was super understated and no one was really paying much attention to her … but then you just don’t expect to see Ellen there as it’s more a haunt of U.K. celebrities.”

A source told Us in August 2025 that DeGeneres had seamlessly adapted to her new life across the pond.

“It’s a different lifestyle for her,” the insider told Us in a cover story. “She’s very chill and in her element.”

According to the source, DeGeneres and de Rossi had been contemplating a move for a while before making the final call.

“They had visited before and looked at homes but weren’t sure when they would do it,” the insider noted. “When they found the right place, they jumped on it.”

Rosie O’Donnell also moved abroad in 2025, settling in Ireland with her then-12-year-old child, Clay.

“I’ve never really known Ellen to say anything political in her life, so I was surprised to read that she left because of President Trump. Like, that shocked me, actually,” O’Donnell exclusively told Us in April 2025. “I’ve been a political person my whole life, not better or worse, it’s just a different way to be in the world. … We’re not really in each other’s worlds, and it’s been kind of awkward, but you know what? I wish her the best. I wish that she has peace and love in her life and that she is OK.”

Months later in July 2025, Trump publicly threatened to revoke O’Donnell’s American citizenship. DeGeneres was vocal in her support of the actress.

“Good for you, @rosie,” DeGeneres wrote via social media at the time.

keywords.name: The former Ellen DeGeneres Show host

summary: Ellen DeGeneres and her wife, Portia de Rossi, moved from Los Angeles to England in fall 2024. The couple, who have been married since 2008, initially purchased acreage in the Cotswolds for a "part-time house" before moving into the country. They made their move permanent after Donald Trump won the presidential election in November 2024. DeGenere and de Rossi have also brought their pets, including a stable of horses, to the UK. They have been regular guests at the exclusive Soho Farmhouse and have been spending most of their time farming, gardening and caring for her pet animals.
shortSummary: Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi, along with their husband, have moved to England's Cotswolds to live a peaceful, rural life, focusing on farming, gardening, and horse care.

Ellen DeGeneres is showing her support for friend Rosie O’Donnell as President Donald Trump erroneously claims to threaten her U.S. citizenship.
“Good for you @rosie,” DeGeneres, 67, wrote via Instagram on Sunday, July 13, sharing screenshots of the president’s post on his social media app, Truth Social, and O’Donnell’s subsequent response.
On Saturday, July 12, President Donald Trump threatened to revoke O’Donnell’s U.S. citizenship, despite having no constitutional authority to do so.
“Because of the fact that Rosie O’Donnell is not in the best interests of our Great Country, I am giving serious consideration to taking away her Citizenship,” Trump wrote on the social media platform. “She is a Threat to Humanity, and should remain in the wonderful Country of Ireland, if they want her. GOD BLESS AMERICA!”
According to expert Julia Gelatt, who spoke to The New York Times, a president does not have the power to take away a U.S-born citizen’s citizenship.
“U.S citizens can relinquish their citizenship voluntarily, and federal courts can strip naturalized citizens of their citizenship if there is proven fraud or misrepresentation or other major cause,” Gelatt, an associate director of the immigration program at the Migration Policy Institute, told the publication. “But U.S.-born citizens cannot have their citizenship taken away.
O’Donnell promptly reacted to the president’s threat, taking to social media to respond.
“Hey donald — you’re rattled again? 18 years later and I still live rent-free in that collapsing brain of yours. You call me a threat to humanity – but I’m everything you fear: a loud woman a queer woman a mother who tells the truth an american who got out of the country b4 u set it ablaze,” O’Donnell 63, wrote via Instagram on Saturday.
“You build walls – I build a life for my autistic kid in a country where decency still exists,” she continued in the post, which featured a picture of the president posting for a photo alongside convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein. “You crave loyalty – I teach my children to question power. You sell fear on golf courses — I nurture, I create, I persist. You are everything that is wrong with america — and I’m everything you hate about what’s still right with it. You want to revoke my citizenship? Go ahead and try, king joffrey with a tangerine spray tan. I’m not yours to silence i never was.”
O’Donnell announced in March that she moved to Ireland and was in the process of getting her citizenship. DeGeneres and her wife, Portia de Rossi, relocated to the English countryside last year. O’Donnell confessed to Us Weekly in an exclusive interview that she hasn’t been in touch with DeGeneres, 67, and was “shocked” by her decision to leave the U.S.
“I’ve never really known Ellen to say anything political in her life, so I was surprised to read that she left because of President Trump. Like, that shocked me, actually,” O’Donnell told Us. I’ve been a political person my whole life, not better or worse, it’s just a different way to be in the world. I was very clear about the reason why I was leaving, and I don’t think it came as a surprise to anyone. We’re not really in each other’s worlds, and it’s been kind of awkward but you know what? I wish her the best. I wish that she has peace and love in her life and that she is OK.”
Despite not having the strongest relationship with DeGeneres, O’Donnell doesn’t have any “malice” towards her whatsoever.
“I don’t want to fight against another gay woman. It’s not like we’re tenaciously opposed to each other. We’re just very different people. We have had some stuff in the past that we never resolved. And not in any way as, as partners or lovers or anything like that, just as friends and comedians, but I wish her the best. I seriously do,” she told Us. “I think that there’s enough room in the world for all of the gay comedians, and we all need to stick together because gay people are the next group to be threatened. And the way they attack trans people is absolutely terrifying. If people don’t understand that they’re a vital part of the LBGTQIA+ community, that’s tragic because we protect our own, especially the most vulnerable.”

Travis Kelce planned out his proposal to now-fiancée Taylor Swift in advance — including asking her parents for her hand in marriage.
“Travis asked Taylor’s parents for their blessing,” a source exclusively tells Us Weekly, referring to the pop star’s mom and dad, Andrea and Scott Swift.
Kelce and Taylor, both 35, announced their engagement on Tuesday, August 25, with a handful of dreamy proposal photos shared via Instagram.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married 🧨 ,” the joint caption read.
In the snaps, Kelce got down on bended knee in the middle of a rose-filled garden and gave Taylor a diamond ring designed by Kindred Lubeck at Artifex Fine Jewelry. The bauble featured an old mine brilliant cut diamond, set on a gold band with smaller stones. It also had a thin bezel.
“Travis is incredibly thoughtful. He had a clear vision of what he wanted,” a second source exclusively told Us. “He did it almost entirely on his own. He knows her so well and what she likes — a timeless, classic, vintage touch.”
According to the second insider, Kelce was “very observant and in tune with” Taylor’s preferred style and wanted to pick out a ring that he knew she’d like.
Taylor and Kelce have been together since summer 2023, making their public debut at one of his Kansas City Chiefs football games the following September. As the pair’s romance blossomed, they started incorporating one another’s families into the fold.
Since becoming a noted fan of the Chiefs, Taylor has attended many of the games and often alongside her parents and her brother, Austin. Travis even gave Scott, a lifelong Philadelphia Eagles fan, a Chiefs-branded lanyard. Scott wore the red-and-gold gear to Swift’s November 2023 Eras Tour concert in Argentina.
“Got him over to the good side, baby,” Travis told his brother Jason Kelce, who used to play for the Eagles, on their “New Heights” podcast at the time. “I might have persuaded him the night before at dinner when I met him. … Maybe, who knows?”
Travis’ bond with the Swifts grew even closer in the offseason. Travis and Taylor both spent a handful of the summer with Scott as he recovered from quintuple bypass surgery.
“Travis was hanging with him the other day,” Taylor said on an episode of Travis’ podcast earlier this month. “He was like, ‘So, uh, sweetie, he says he’s at 75 percent and if this is 75 percent, I’m truly terrified to give you the update.’ My dad’s like, ‘New arteries, new me.’”

Travis Kelce knelt to the ground and pulled out a (massive) ring for Taylor Swift — and Us Weekly has all the details.
The couple took to Instagram on Tuesday, August 26, to share photos of their engagement. In one pic, Kelce, 35, held hands with Swift, also 35, while showing off her new rock. The ring featured an old mine brilliant cut diamond set on a gold band with more small stones. Designed by Kindred Lubeck at Artifex Fine Jewelry, the design was complete with a thin bezel. (An old mine brilliant cut dimaond is a pre-modern stone that is characterized by its imperfect symmetry, cushion shape and chunky facets.)
As for the cost, jewelry expert Nilesh Rakholia estimated the ring to be worth $950,000 to $1,270,000. The Abelini founder told Us, “The stone itself looks to be easily in the 7–10 carat range, which immediately places it among the most iconic celebrity engagement rings.”
Another jeweler Laura Taylor, who specializes in engagement and wedding rings, told Us that the ring could be up to 12 carats. Taylor agreed that it was “easily worth” $1 million.
Swift teamed the massive diamond with a Cartier watch complete with a matching gold wristlet and diamond face.
In the sweet photos, Kelce got on one knee while wearing a Ralph Lauren navy blue shirt and white pants. Swift, for her part, stunned in a white top which was embellished with veritable stripes, thin straps and a flared hem. She teamed the look with an A-line flowy midi skirt. Swift put a hand on Kelce’s cheek while they were surrounded by a garden of flowers.
In another shot, the duo closed their eyes and pressed their foreheads together while donning soft smiles. They also cuddled up together while relaxing on a bench under more florals.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married 🧨,” Swift captioned the post with “So High School,” her hit song about Kelce playing in the background.
On Tuesday, an insider exclusively revealed to Us how Travis picked out the perfect engagement ring for Taylor. “Travis is incredibly thoughtful. He had a clear vision of what he wanted,” the source said. “He did it almost entirely on his own. He knows her so well and what she likes — a timeless, classic, vintage touch.”
The insider added, Travis is “very observant and in tune with” Swift’s preferred style. “That drove his decision,” the insider told Us. “He considered everything about what she’d like and want, and he paid attention to the jewelry she wears often for inspiration.”
Swift and Kelce started dating in the summer of 2023 after he attended her Eras Tour and wanted to meet her. While they did not meet at her concert because Swift was not offering meet and greets, they later got in contact after Kelce said he wanted to give her his number during an episode of his “New Heights” podcast.
In December 2023, a source exclusively told Us Weekly that the lovebirds “had plenty of really deep conversations about their future together” and always tried to make “as much time for each other as possible.
In April 2024, another insider revealed that Swift was happy not feeling like she had to “hide” while dating Kelce. “[He] makes her feel safe and protected like she has the freedom to be and act however she wants.”

Ellen DeGeneres is not second-guessing her and wife Portia de Rossi’s decision to move to the U.K.
While appearing for a live conversation with English broadcaster Richard Bacon on Sunday, July 20, DeGeneres, 67, was asked whether she relocated to England because of President Donald Trump’s reelection.
“Yes,” she replied, per the BBC.
DeGeneres explained that she and de Rossi, 52, were initially planning to spend three or four months per year in the U.K. at a “part time house” before the 2024 election outcome.
“We got here the day before the election and woke up to lots of texts from our friends with crying emojis, and I was like, ‘He got in,'” she recalled of Trump, 79. “And we’re like, ‘We’re staying here.’”
DeGeneres gushed that her new life across the pond with de Rossi is “absolutely beautiful.” (DeGeneres and de Rossi tied the knot in 2008.)
“We’re just not used to seeing this kind of beauty. The villages and the towns and the architecture — everything you see is charming and it’s just a simpler way of life,” DeGeneres said. “It’s clean. Everything here is just better — the way animals are treated, people are polite. I just love it here.”
She continued, “We moved here in November, which was not the ideal time, but I saw snow for the first time in my life. We love it here. Portia flew her horses here, and I have chickens, and we had sheep for about two weeks.”
After DeGeneres and de Rossi relocated to the English countryside, Rosie O’Donnell admitted to Us Weekly that she hadn’t been in contact with the former talk show host and was “shocked” by her decision to leave the U.S.
“I’ve never really known Ellen to say anything political in her life, so I was surprised to read that she left because of President Trump. Like, that shocked me, actually,” O’Donnell, 63, told Us in April. I’ve been a political person my whole life, not better or worse, it’s just a different way to be in the world. I was very clear about the reason why I was leaving, and I don’t think it came as a surprise to anyone. We’re not really in each other’s worlds, and it’s been kind of awkward but you know what? I wish her the best. I wish that she has peace and love in her life and that she is OK.”

Ellen DeGeneres and her wife, Portia de Rossi, have completely settled across the pond — and their home is a chic sight to behold.
“Our sheep keep coming inside,” DeGeneres, 67, wrote via Instagram on Monday, June 18. “To be fair, we do have a piece of furniture that looks like a sheep, but that one doesn’t try to eat our rugs.”
The former Ellen DeGeneres Show host uploaded a video of four sheep wandering inside her home via sliding glass doors. The menagerie of farm animals wandered into the living area, which included a flannel blanket draped over a leather armchair and a copper-colored striped area rug. There is also a fluffy, white bed for DeGeneres’ dog to rest.
In another portion of the clip, DeGeneres filmed one of the sheep walking through the glass door into another room. The animal even walked past a sculpture that looked like a sheep.
“Yes we have house sheep,” she jokingly added in her caption.
While DeGeneres was seemingly preoccupied by the unexpected houseguests, many of her social media followers were amazed by the home decor in the background.
“I need to see a full home tour, please 👏😍,” HGTV maven Joanna Gaines wrote via Instagram comment, while another social media user added, “Love the house 😍.”
DeGeneres and de Rossi, 52, relocated from Montecito, California, to the Cotswolds in England late last year.
“My wife. My best friend. The love of my life. Thank you for being you and loving me,” DeGeneres gushed about her wife via Instagram in December 2024, before detailing their international move. “So happy we get to travel and explore the world together in the next 20 years, and looking forward to our first snowy Christmas.”
At the time, DeGeneres simply called their residence a “farmhouse.”
The couple, who wed in 2008, have also hit up local hotspots such as Soho Farmhouse.
“She was with two female friends walking from the car park towards the farm buildings where the clubhouse is — we passed on a stone bridge over a stream,” an eyewitness exclusively told Us Weekly in November 2024. “She was dressed in a country casual way. She was super understated and no one was really paying much attention to her … but then you just don’t expect to see Ellen there as it’s more a haunt of U.K. celebrities.”
While DeGeneres and de Rossi have remained relatively mum about their life in the British countryside, the Finding Dory star has long had a passion for interiors.
“[Portia is] as passionate about horses as I am about houses. But we don’t delve into each other’s silos,” DeGeneres jokingly told The Montecito Journal in 2023. “In fact, I can’t really get her to go into a furniture store with me unless there’s a horse in there somewhere.”

On a Sunday afternoon in late July, Ellen DeGeneres walked onto the stage at the historic Cheltenham Everyman Theatre in Cheltenham, England, to the tune of Harry Styles’ “You’re So Golden,” then sat in front of a crowd of nearly 700 people for a surprise Q&A session. During the event, the former talk show host — who’s remained mostly under the radar since ending her long-running chatfest in 2022 — discussed everything from her early days in showbiz to her 2020 fall from grace to what the future holds.
She also shed light on her recent decision to leave her beloved Montecito, California, neighborhood for greener pastures in the U.K. In November 2024, DeGeneres, 67, and her wife of 17 years, Portia de Rossi, 52, officially relocated to the Cotswolds — an idyllic region in the English countryside filled with rolling hills, stone cottages… and posh yet privacy-seeking A-listers like David and Victoria Beckham. “It’s absolutely beautiful,” she told the audience of her adopted home. “Everything here is better.”
According to sources, DeGeneres has found her happy place. She spends her days contentedly tending to her chickens, ushering sheep out of her open-air living room and walking to the local pub for lunch. “It’s a different lifestyle for her,” an insider tells Us Weekly. “She’s very chill and in her element.” She and de Rossi reside in a stunning 10,000-square-foot home called Hiaven, which they bought for a reported $26 million. (Their original Cotswolds property, Kitesbridge Farm, is currently up for sale for $30 million.)
It’s a new chapter for DeGeneres — and also a chance for a career refresh. “I do like my chickens here, but I am a little bit bored,” she told English broadcaster and host Richard Bacon during her July 20 event, noting that she’s still figuring out her next moves. (Just days later, it was announced that DeGeneres had signed with WME talent agency.) “I don’t know what I’m going to do yet,” she said. “I’m going to pick it very carefully.”
DeGeneres and de Rossi had been contemplating a move across the pond for some time. “They had visited before and looked at homes but weren’t sure when they would do it,” says an insider. “When they found the right place, they jumped on it.” They initially planned to stay in England just a few months out of the year, but decided to make it their permanent residence after the 2024 election. DeGeneres said in the Q&A that she and de Rossi were in the Cotswolds when Donald Trump’s presidency was announced. “We were like, ‘We’re staying here. We’re not going back.’” (They opted to sell Kitesbridge and move to Hiaven because, according to DeGeneres, the newer home has a horse facility and de Rossi “couldn’t live without her horses.”)
She’s leaning into country living. “Ellen’s been farming and gardening and taking care of her animals,” says the insider. DeGeneres has shared photos and videos of her doing all of the above with her 135 million followers on Instagram, as well as footage of her and de Rossi rowing a boat and mowing the lawn on their sprawling 100-acre property, located in the cozy village of Great Tew. “Those close to her have never seen her happier.” DeGeneres raved about the U.K. to Bacon, saying she loves the “absolutely beautiful” scenery and architecture, adding, “I really like the people and [the] fish and chips are delicious. Everything you see is charming, and it’s just a simpler way of life.”
Privacy is a huge concern for DeGeneres and de Rossi, but they’ve been chatting up the locals. “[Ellen and Portia] have interesting things to say,” shares a source. “They were friendly to local people and wanted to live normal lives, but were nervous of any press attention.” Adds a Great Tew resident: “I’ve only met them very briefly, but from what I’ve heard, everyone who has spent time with them seems to suggest they are very nice, good company and genuinely committed to making England their home.”
Still, many locals seem to be unaware of DeGerenes’ celebrity status. A second source from the area tells Us several residents revealed that they had “never heard” of the comedian when asked about her. “But then again, horsey people — and there are a lot of them around here — don’t watch afternoon TV,” explains the source. Whether DeGeneres is recognized or not, the Great Tew resident believes she and de Rossi have gotten a warm reception from the community. “To my knowledge, there’s been nothing ‘frosty’ happening around here. I think this side of the Cotswolds is very welcoming and friendly.”
The pair are regulars at the exclusive members’ club Soho Farmhouse and have been spotted getting Sunday lunch at the Falkland Arms pub, a 16th-century inn in the center of town. “It’s a maze of cozy nooks and crannies, shadowy and often dimly lit with low ceilings and a hearty atmosphere,” a pub-goer says. “Ellen and Portia can easily slip in unnoticed.”
They’ve also been spending time with famous friends. They attended a star-studded party at British TV presenter Jeremy Clarkson’s The Farmer’s Dog pub in November 2024 and grabbed dinner with fellow former talk show host James Corden at the Chiltern Firehouse in London to celebrate de Rossi’s birthday in February. (Corden purchased a property about an hour away from Great Tew in Oxfordshire.) “They have a good friend group,” says the insider, adding that DeGeneres has traveled to the States a few times since the move to see people.
It hasn’t all been picture-perfect. A third source says DeGeneres and de Rossi had a “rocky start” in the Cotswolds. The Kitesbridge Farm area was flooded just days after they moved in following a severe windstorm, and they had to find their footing while adjusting to farm life. “Things weren’t quite as luxurious as they’d been in Montecito,” says the source, noting that the duo was spotted collecting their own trash bins from the end of their 700-foot driveway one blustery fall day. DeGeneres admitted in her Q&A that the chilly gray weather took some getting used to. “The winter is tough,” she confessed, “but I still enjoyed it because we’re not used to seasons in California.”
Another ‘Hollywood’ problem? The third source says that two of the couple’s cars, a vintage Land Rover Defender and a Land Rover Discovery, are too big to get over a width- and weight-restricted bridge that leads directly into town. “[They’ve] gotten used to taking the long way around to the village — a three-mile trip,” shares the source, who notes that DeGeneres and de Rossi have also been seen walking to town on foot. “[It’s] probably quicker than the long-way-around drive.”
The third source also says the more modern Hiaven — with its floor-to-ceiling windows and infinity pool — has been a better fit for the couple. (Andrew Barnes, a senior director of U.K. Sotheby’s International Realty, told the Wall Street Journal the house looks like it belongs “in Malibu.”) “[Ellen and Portia] went from a traditional farmhouse to something much more Hollywood,” a source said in March. Some unexpectedly dark history about the property? The mansion was built near the site of a since-demolished farmhouse where a murder took place. In 2021, social worker Lynda Rickard was sentenced to jail for forging the will of her millionaire landlord, Anthony Sootheran, and then depriving him of food and medical help in order to inherit part of his estate.
Overall, relocating has brought DeGeneres and de Rossi closer. “There’s less work stress and more shared activities,” explains the insider. The pair were spotted holding hands during a romantic stroll on Bond Street in London on July 29. “It’s a calmer Ellen, so she’s easier to be around. And Portia is really enjoying it.” The Arrested Development alum retired from acting in 2018. “Portia quit acting a long time ago, so she wasn’t leaving her career,” the insider adds. “She was already scaling back.”
The cross-continent move has given DeGeneres some welcome distance from Hollywood. In 2020, after Buzzfeed published a report in which former employees of The Ellen DeGeneres Show accused top brass of mistreatment and discrimination, a formal investigation was launched. (DeGeneres had been dragged a few months prior on X [formerly Twitter] when a comedy writer’s thread about her being “mean” went viral.) That September, she publicly apologized on her talk show, saying in part, “I know that I’m in a position of privilege and power, and I realize that with that comes responsibility, and I take responsibility for what happens at my show.”
Though the chatfest went on for two more years, the damage was done. The insider says DeGeneres felt “pushed out” of industry circles. “The investigation into her show was a major blow.” Adds a second insider: “Ellen feels very burned by how the world turned on her.” She addressed being canceled in her 2024 Netflix special, For Your Approval, in which she joked about being “kicked out of show business.” During her July 20 sit-down, she said the sting of the scandal remains. “I hate that people think that I am [mean]. Because I know who I am. I know that I am an empathetic and compassionate person. And so it hurts my feelings.”
She’s now weighing her options about what to do next professionally. “I am always happiest on stage,” she told Bacon. “It’s the best feeling.” (She also said she’d love to do another talk show based in the U.K., but isn’t sure the format works anymore.) For now, the first insider says DeGeneres is “embracing this reinvention. She’s left the Hollywood drama behind for a more peaceful life.”
For more on Ellen DeGeneres, watch the exclusive video above and pick up the latest issue of Us Weekly — on newsstands now.

Ellen DeGeneres and her wife, Portia de Rossi, have left the United States and they don’t plan to return.
DeGeneres, 66, and de Rossi, 51, moved out of their Montecito, California home and relocated to the Cotswolds, a rural region of England about two hours outside of London, according to a report from TMZ.
The couple, who married in 2008, plan to sell their California property and are still mulling over how much to ask for it. They sold their other mansion, a 10-acre property in Santa Barbara County, for $96 million in August.
DeGeneres recently concluded her “Ellen’s Last Stand” tour, which came with an accompanying Netflix special titled “For Your Approval.”
In the special, DeGeneres opened up about being, in her words, “kicked out of show business” following the toxic workplace allegations that surfaced around her time hosting The Ellen DeGeneres Show from 2003 to 2022. She told the audience she is proud of who she has become in the aftermath of the scandal.
“[I’m] just a multifaceted person with different feelings and emotions, and I can be happy and sad and compassionate or frustrated,” she said. “I have OCD and ADD. I’m honest. I’m generous. I’m sensitive and thoughtful. But I’m tough and I’m impatient and I’m demanding. I’m direct. I’m a strong woman.”
She added that after spending her entire career worried about what other people think of her, she “just can’t anymore.”
“I’m sure you’ve heard the saying, ‘What other people think of me is none of my business.’ People will say and think all kinds of things and you have no control over that. But you know the truth and that’s all that matters,” DeGeneres said. “But that is easier said than done. Because being in this business, I’ve had to care what people think. Because being a comedian or a host, it’s our only real currency for success. If they like you, you’re in, and if they don’t, you’re out. And I’ve spent an entire lifetime trying to make people happy, and I’ve cared far too much what other people think of me.”
DeGeneres has made such honesty a staple of her act over the years and has been candid about coming out and the challenges she faced being a lesbian in show business.
She met de Rossi in 2000, three years after she first came out. Their relationship didn’t turn romantic until 2004, and when it did, de Rossi said it gave her the courage to be open about her sexuality as well.
“I respect her so much. She was so courageous and so loud in ’97, and now she is doing something that is more subliminal,” de Rossi told The Advocate in 2005. “She’s changing the world, she really is, and it’s exciting to be a part of that.”
When the allegations against DeGeneres first arose, de Rossi stood by her wife and she doesn’t appear to have wavered. On the couple’s 16th wedding anniversary on August 16, Ellen wrote via Instagram “I’m so lucky to be loved by the most amazing person I’ve ever met. I love you Portia. You’re my everything.”

Rosie O’Donnell is settling into her new life in Ireland with her family.
“We chose Ireland and didn’t really know where to go,” O’Donnell exclusively told Us Weekly of her new home country while discussing her Hulu documentary special Unleashing Hope: The Power of Service Dogs for Children With Autism. “And someone said Dalkey and I found a house online that was in Glengarry. But when the people who were helping us move in went there, there was mold in it.”
O’Donnell shared that after “black mold” was discovered in their home, she had to rethink their living situation for the sake of her family’s health. (O’Donnell moved to Ireland with her 12-year-old child, Clay, who has autism.)
“[We] could not move there, especially with an autistic child who has some allergy issues,” she explained. “And so we ended up in Howth.”
When arriving in Howth, O’Donnell and Clay stayed in an Airbnb, which was a short-term solution. Once their time was up there, O’Donnell and Clay officially settled in Dublin and couldn’t be happier.
“There’s a great, great school there. And Clay has done very well. And they were really welcoming,” the actress recalled. “And I love the little town, the little village. It’s in the heart of Dublin, but it’s still a village where you know the name of the grocer and you know the name of the cashiers. People are unbearably kind in a way that shocks me every single day.”
O’Donnell announced last month that she moved to Ireland and was in the process of getting her citizenship. The former talk show host isn’t the only A-List star who has relocated across the pond recently, either. Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi relocated to the English countryside last year. O’Donnell confessed to Us that she hasn’t been in touch with DeGeneres, 67, and was “shocked” by her decision to leave the U.S.
“I’ve never really known Ellen to say anything political in her life, so I was surprised to read that she left because of President Trump. Like, that shocked me, actually,” O’Donnell told Us. I’ve been a political person my whole life, not better or worse, it’s just a different way to be in the world. I was very clear about the reason why I was leaving, and I don’t think it came as a surprise to anyone. We’re not really in each other’s worlds, and it’s been kind of awkward but you know what? I wish her the best. I wish that she has peace and love in her life and that she is OK.”
Despite not having the strongest relationship with DeGeneres, O’Donnell doesn’t have any “malice” towards her whatsoever.
“I don’t want to fight against another gay woman. It’s not like we’re tenaciously opposed to each other. We’re just very different people. We have had some stuff in the past that we never resolved. And not in any way as, as partners or lovers or anything like that, just as friends and comedians, but I wish her the best. I seriously do,” she told Us. “I think that there’s enough room in the world for all of the gay comedians, and we all need to stick together because gay people are the next group to be threatened. And the way they attack trans people is absolutely terrifying. If people don’t understand that they’re a vital part of the LBGTQIA+ community, that’s tragic because we protect our own, especially the most vulnerable.”
While O’Donnell is putting down roots in a new country, she confessed that she misses her adult children and friends who remain in the States. Before moving, O’Donnell would consistently have group phone chats with her pals. Now, she hasn’t been able to jump on those treasured calls as much as she likes.
“It’s been very hard because of the time zone for me to participate in that. And I really miss that,” she explained, noting that she still keeps in touch with her inner circle. “I call my kids, I FaceTime my kids. I have two best friends, Junie and Jackie, since I [was] 3 years old. They’re really like sisters. And I talk to them all the time. I have two brothers I’m very close to. I talk to them all the time.”
Despite missing her family, O’Donnell said she doesn’t regret her decision to move.
“I know myself enough to know that this was something I needed to do for the safety and sanity of myself and my non-binary child,” she said.
In addition to focusing on Clay’s mental health, O’Donnell is ensuring that Clay is living the best life they can. O’Donnell and Clay’s journey is featured in Hulu’s Unleashing Hope, a documentary that focuses on the impact service dogs have on families affected by autism. O’Donnell was grateful to use her platform to shine a light on the value of the initiative.
“It’s been really a difficult but beautiful journey,” O’Donnell told Us, while recalling her immediate reaction to Clay’s diagnosis. “I knew very much. I worked with Autism Speaks. I had seen many, many documentaries and even produced one called A Mother’s Courage. There was a familiarity there and there was something that felt familiar to me.”
Unleashing Hope: The Power of Service Dogs for Children With Autism is available to stream now on Hulu.

America, and Hollywood specifically, has been home to celebrities for decades — but in recent years, some stars have decided to leave the United States and settle overseas.
Ellen DeGeneres and wife Portia de Rossi chose to leave the sunshine state in 2024 for a more relaxed lifestyle in the United Kingdom.
A local source exclusively told Us Weekly in November 2024 that DeGeneres is “definitely a lot less well-known” in the U.K. but “she’s still famous.” The insider added that Cotswolds, where the couple reportedly settled, is all about anonymity.
“People know who she is but the thing about the Cotswolds is no one gives a f— if you’re Kate Moss or the farmer’s wife,” the source said.
While DeGeneres and de Rossi didn’t instantly announce their relocation, other celebrities have been much more vocal about their U.S. exit. Richard Gere pointed to his wife’s heritage as his reason to move to Spain, while Rosie O’Donnell headed to Ireland in 2025 after President Donald Trump began his second term.
Scroll down to see which A-listers no longer live in the U.S. — or call another country their primary residence:
Rosie O’Donnell
O’Donnell revealed in March 2025 that she and child Clay relocated from New York City to Ireland that January days before Trump was sworn in as president. “[I’m] in the process of getting my Irish citizenship, as I have Irish grandparents,” the actress explained via a TikTok video. “And that’s what’s going on, and that’s where I’ve been and what I’ve been doing. And although I was never someone who thought I would move to another country, that’s what I decided would be the best for myself and my 12-year-old child. And here we are.”
The A League of Their Own actress adopted Dakota, whose nickname is Clay, in 2013 with her late ex-wife Michelle Rounds, to whom she was married from 2012 to 2015. (O’Donnell adopted her four eldest children — Parker, Chelsea, Blake and Vivienne — with her first wife, Kelli Carpenter.)
Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi
News broke in November 2024 that the former Ellen DeGeneres Show host and her wife left their Montecito, California, home and moved to the rural area of the Costwolds, which is two hours outside of London.
DeGeneres spoke about the move for the first time in a July 2025 interview, replying “yes” when asked if the move was a result of President Trump’s 2024 election win.
“We got here the day before the election and woke up to lots of texts from our friends with crying emojis, and I was like, ‘He got in,’” she told English broadcaster Richard Bacon at the time. “And we’re like, ‘We’re staying here.’”
The former TV host said it was “absolutely beautiful” in England.
“We’re just not used to seeing this kind of beauty. The villages and the towns and the architecture — everything you see is charming and it’s just a simpler way of life,” DeGeneres added. “It’s clean. Everything here is just better — the way animals are treated, people are polite. I just love it here.”
Eva Longoria
After spending much of her adult life in Los Angeles, Longoria revealed to Marie Claire in November 2024 that she and husband José Bastón had been living between Spain and Mexico for the past few years. (The couple share son Santiago.)
“The vibe was different,” Longoria told the outlet when asked what made her want to leave L.A. “And then Covid happened, and it pushed it over the edge. Whether it’s the homelessness or the taxes — not that I want to s— on California — it just feels like this chapter in my life is done now.”
Christina Milian
The singer relocated her family from Hollywood to France because of her husband’s heritage. “My husband is French, and we’ve been together for over seven or eight years, and for, like, the last three or four years, we were commuting back and forth every six months,” Milian explained during a November 2024 appearance on The Jennifer Hudson Show. “And then we decided to commit to it last year because our kids were going to go to school.”
Milian said she loves living overseas, noting her three children are “all going to school in Paris. What better an opportunity than that.” (Milian shares sons Isaiah and Kenna with husband Matt Pokora, whom she wed in 2020. She shares her eldest child, daughter Violet, with ex The Dream.)
Amber Heard
Us confirmed in May 2024 that Heard relocated from the U.S. to Spain with her daughter, Oonagh, whom she welcomed via surrogate in 2021.
“Amber doesn’t want to raise a child in Hollywood,” a source exclusively told Us at the time, claiming the actress “never liked the energy” of Los Angeles. “She [thinks] Madrid is a more welcoming place for her. She feels safe and secure, and she’s surrounded by better people where she is.”
Richard Gere
The Pretty Woman actor revealed in March 2024 that he planned to move to his wife Alejandra Silva’s home country of Spain that fall with their two children.
“For Alejandra, it will be wonderful to be closer to her family, her lifelong friends and her culture,” Gere told Vanity Fair Spain at the time of his wife, who was born in Spain. “She was very generous in giving me six years living in my world, so it is only fair that I give her at least another six living in hers.”
Gere followed through with his plans, selling his $11 million Connecticut home in October 2024. However, the actor still has a house somewhere in the New York countryside.
Shania Twain
Twain was born and raised in Canada but moved to the U.S. once she signed her first country music contract. However, her primary residence is in Corseaux, Switzerland, with husband Frédéric Thiébaud. In March 2023, after living in Europe for 10 years, CNN reported that she had a Golden Pass Express train named after her: the Shania Train.
Lily Collins
The Emily in Paris actress and her husband, Charlie McDowell, moved to Copenhagen from the States in 2023, Vogue previously reported. (The couple, who welcomed their first baby via surrogate in 2025, reportedly still have property on the West Coast.)
When asked what she loves most about Denmark, Collins told Elle Denmark in September 2023, “Life here is just so wonderful and so calm and bright. What I love so much is that there’s so much color and, yet, it’s so calm. I love being able to bike everywhere. It feels like a big city but also very intimate, and everyone is so nice.”
George Clooney
Years after marrying Amal Clooney in 2014, George picked up his life in the U.S. and bought a house in the south of France in 2021. “The property is magical,” a source exclusively told Us in September 2024, noting it’s the family’s primary residence. “They have hundreds of acres, a vineyard and olive trees, and the kids can be outside and totally protected. There’s a small village nearby with shops. It’s a very simple life, and George loves it.”
George and Amal, who share twins Ella and Alexander, also own a villa in Lake Como, Italy. His real estate portfolio also includes homes in New York, England and Mexico.
Pamela Anderson
When the pandemic hit in 2020, Anderson chose to move back to her home country, Vancouver Island, British Columbia. “A few years back, I kind of gave up at some point and needed a change,” Anderson told Better Homes & Gardens in August 2024, attributing the move to how the public perceived her. “I thought, ‘Well, I guess that’s just what people think of me.’ I was not in a good space when I moved back to Canada.”
The Baywatch alum added: “I don’t know what happened over the last few decades, but I feel now so far removed from the image of who I was. I felt very sad and lonely. I didn’t feel just misunderstood, I felt like I had really screwed up, that my whole life was a bundle of mistakes. I was hard on myself, and I thought I put my family through a lot and put my kids through so much.”
Josh Lucas
The Sweet Home Alabama actor gushed about living in Indonesia in 2019, telling Jimmy Kimmel that the country had an environmentally-focused school that his son attended. Lucas, who is from Arkansas, shares one child with ex-wife Jessica Ciencin Henriquez.
“I have this very special 7-year-old child, and I think all of us are trying to figure out how to have an impact in the world, and for myself, the best thing I could do is give my son this extraordinary experience,” Lucas said during a Jimmy Kimmel Live! appearance. “Being on the other side of the world and looking back at this madness is amazing.”
Courtney Love
The musician has resided in London since 2019. Love explained in March 2025 that she is in the process of getting her British citizenship.
Melissa George
George uprooted her life from New York City to Paris in 2016, bringing her two sons along for the ride. The actress purchased a home in nearby Provence in 2020, which was featured in a New York Times Magazine home tour video.
Lindsay Lohan
The Parent Trap actress left the U.S. in 2014 and began living in Dubai, where she eventually met her husband, Bader Shammas. The couple, who welcomed son Luai in July 2023, are currently raising him in the United Arab Emirates.
“I love living in New York, but I do love the serenity and peace that I find living in the Middle East because there are no cameras in Dubai,” Lohan told Entertainment Tonight in December 2017. “And I can actually focus on what I want to do in life.”

Ellen DeGeneres
Ellen DeGeneres got her start in stand-up comedy before making a name for herself in television. She starred on the sitcom Ellen from 1994 to 1998 and went on to host the Emmy-winning daytime talk show The Ellen DeGeneres Show from 2003 to 2022. Since coming out as a lesbian on The Oprah Winfrey Show in 1997, DeGeneres has used her platform to explore issues facing the LGBTQ+ community.
DeGeneres is also known for voicing Dory in the Disney films Finding Nemo (2003) and Finding Dory (2016). She has hosted the Academy Awards, the Grammy Awards and the Primetime Emmys and has authored four books. She received the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor in 2012 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2016.
Four years after they met at a party, DeGeneres started dating actress Portia De Rossi in 2004. The duo announced their plans to say “I do” after a May 2008 California Supreme Court ruling granted same sex couples the right to legally marry. In August 2008, they tied the knot in front of friends and family at their Beverly Hills home. In 2024, the pair were living in England.

Kylie Kelce reacted to her brother-in-law Travis Kelce’s engagement to Taylor Swift.
After Travis and Swift, 35, announced their engagement on Tuesday, August 26, Kylie, 33, showed her subtle nod of approval by liking the couple’s joint Instagram post.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married 🧨,” Swift and Kelce wrote, sharing a carousel of photos from the proposal.
Kylie has been married to Travis’ older brother, Jason Kelce, since April 2018.
Among the first to react to the engagement were Travis’ Kansas City Chiefs quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, and his wife, Brittany Mahomes, who has become good friends with Swift.
Patrick, 29, responded via his Instagram Story on Tuesday, sharing an engagement picture of the couple with three red-heart emojis.
Brittany, 29, also reacted to the engagement news on Tuesday, writing via her Instagram Story, “Two of the most genuine people meet & fall in love. Just so happy for these two. 🥹🤍.”
The “New Heights” podcast, which Travis and Jason cohost, reacted enthusiastically in a series of posts on Tuesday.
“NEW NEWS,” the podcast’s official Instagram posted, a reference to a popular segment on the show. “Congrats to @taylorswift @killatrav.”
The podcast also shared one of the couple’s engagement photos with a Photoshopped image of a shirtless, screaming Jason in the background.
“This pretty much sums up everyone’s reaction 😅,” the “New Heights” account wrote.
Swift made her first appearance on “New Heights” earlier this month, where she recalled how Travis initially tried to woo her in July 2023.
“This kind of felt more like I was in an 80s John Hughes movie and he was just, like, standing outside of my window with a boombox just being like, ‘I want to date you. Do you want to go on a date with me? I made you a friendship bracelet, do you want to go on a date with me?’” she joked. “I was like, ‘If this guy isn’t crazy, which is a big if, but if he’s not crazy then this is basically like every song I’ve ever written since I was a teenager come to life.’”

Ellen DeGeneres is taking in the British sights amid news that she and her wife, actress Portia de Rossi, moved across the pond.
DeGeneres, 66, was recently spotted at the famed U.K. hotspot Soho Farmhouse earlier this month, according to an eyewitness.
“She was with two female friends walking from the car park towards the farm buildings where the clubhouse is — we passed on a stone bridge over a stream,” the fellow guest exclusively tells Us Weekly. “She was dressed in a country casual way. She was super understated and no one was really paying much attention to her … but then you just don’t expect to see Ellen there as it’s more a haunt of U.K. celebrities.”
The insider initially thought that DeGeneres was an uncanny doppelgänger for the former Ellen DeGeneres Show host until hearing her speak to an acquaintance.
Soho Farmhouse is a luxurious member’s club and hotel in The Cotswolds, where the likes of David Beckham, Victoria Beckham, Sharon Osbourne and Simon Cowell are known to frequent.
“Soho House is a club for creatives. We exist to provide a home for our members to come together and belong, wherever they are in the world,” a website description reads. “Today, we have Houses across the world, and each one is designed to be comfortable and characterful, offering our members a unique yet familiar experience every time they visit. The Houses have spaces for drinking, dining, relaxing, working and exercising.”
Another local tells Us that DeGeneres is “definitely a lot less well-known” in the U.K. but “she’s still famous,” adding, “People know who she is but the thing about the Cotswolds is no one gives a f— if you’re Kate Moss or the farmer’s wife.”
The Cotswolds location of Soho Farmhouse sits two hours outside the hustle and bustle of capital city London.
News broke on Thursday, November 21, that DeGeneres and de Rossi, 51, moved away from California, to a new residence in the Cotswolds. They have not publicly addressed the move.
DeGeneres and the Scandal alum have been married since 2008, where they lived in a sprawling mansion in Montecito, California and were notably neighbors to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, who coincidentally moved from the U.K. in 2020. (Harry, 40, and Meghan, 43, relocated to the United States after stepping down from their duties as senior working royals.)
“We were home and we saw you guys, which was great,” Meghan recalled to DeGeneres during a November 2021 appearance on her eponymous talk show about Halloween. “We wanted to do something fun for the kids and then the kids were just not into it at all.”
Harry and Meghan, who share 5-year-old Prince Archie and 3-year-old Princess Lilibet, also attended DeGeneres and de Rossi’s vow renewal ceremony in February 2023.

Ellen DeGeneres and wife Portia de Rossi are selling the U.K. house they moved to after permanently leaving the U.S.
According to a report by The Wall Street Journal published on Tuesday, July 22, the couple’s 43-acre estate in the Cotswolds, named Kitesbridge Farm, is listed for approximately $30 million.
The outlet noted that DeGeneres, 67, and de Rossi, 52, paid “about $20 million” for the property in spring 2024, ahead of the pair relocating from California to England in the aftermath of President Donald Trump’s reelection.
In a statement shared with the outlet on Tuesday, DeGeneres explained her family’s decision regarding their original English retreat. “When we decided to live here full-time, we knew that Portia couldn’t live without her horses,” the statement read. “We needed a home that had a horse facility and pastures for them.”
The couple, who married in August 2008, reportedly relocated to a nearby home in the U.K. that serves as a more appropriate base for de Rossi’s animals.
On the market via Sotheby’s International Realty, the seven-bedroom, seven-bathroom estate was “imagined over the past year,” per the property’s listing.
It also features a two-bedroom guest cottage with a kitchen and sitting room, plus a heated five-car garage with its own kitchenette, a “party barn” with a bar, a heated indoor swimming pool, a gym, helicopter shed, a kitchen garden, multiple outdoor living areas and a covered dining space within a courtyard.
DeGeneres confirmed her decision to leave the U.S. during a live conversation with British broadcaster Richard Bacon on Sunday, July 20. She explained at the event, staged at the Everyman Theatre in Cheltenham, that she and de Rossi planned on living in the Cotswolds for “three months of the year, or four months of the year,” but decided to stay permanently after Trump, 79, became president.
“We got here the day before the election and we woke up to lots of texts from our friends and crying emojis,” DeGeneres told the crowd at Sunday’s event. “We were like, ‘We’re staying here, we’re not going back, we are not leaving.’ So, yeah, we bought a house that we thought was going to be a part-time house, then we decided we needed a different house, and now we’re selling that house. If anybody wants a house. It’s a beautiful house. It’s a beautiful stone farmhouse.”
DeGeneres also touched on what she loves about life in the U.K., revealing that “the people” are favorable, as is one of the nation’s most famed dishes. “Fish and chips are delicious, yes,” she said before praising the British countryside. “It’s absolutely beautiful. We are just not used to seeing this kind of beauty,” DeGeneres explained. “Everything you see is charming, and it’s just a simpler way of life. It’s clean and everything here is better. The way animals are treated, the way people are polite. I just love it here.”

Bruce Willis is living in a second home amid his battle with frontotemporal dementia, wife Emma Heming Willis revealed during Emma and Bruce Willis: The Unexpected Journey – A Diane Sawyer Special.
“It was one of the hardest decisions that I’ve had to make so far,” Heming Willis, 47, said in the ABC special that aired on Tuesday, August 26. “But I knew, first and foremost, Bruce would want that for our daughters. You know, he would want them to be in a home that was more tailored to their needs, not his needs.”
Their second home is a one story house where Bruce lives full-time with his care team, which is not far from the family’s first home. Heming Willis, who wed Willis in 2009, said she and their daughters — Mabel, 13, and Evelyn, 11 — spend “a lot” of time at the second home with Willis, including visits for breakfast and dinner. (Willis also shares daughters Rumer, 37, Scout, 34, and Tallulah, 31, with ex-wife Demi Moore.)
The Die Hard actor’s family revealed in March 2022 he was retiring from acting after he was diagnosed with aphasia. According to Mayo Clinic, aphasia is a language disorder that affects how a person communicates. It can impact their speech, the way they write and the way they understand both spoken and written language.
Nearly one year later, Willis’ family confirmed his condition had progressed to frontotemporal dementia, also known as FTD. It’s an umbrella term for a group of brain diseases that affect the brain’s frontal and temporal lobes, which are areas that are associated with personality, behavior and language.
Willis’ family has continued to share updates of his health journey with fans, but they gave the most intimate look inside Willis’ life now on the ABC special. Heming Willis opened up about when she started noticing the first signs of her husband’s cognitive health decline.
“For someone who is very talkative and very engaged, he was just a little more quiet. And when the family would get together, he would kind of just melt a little bit,” Heming Willis said during a sit-down interview with ABC’s Diane Sawyer. “It felt a little removed, very cold, not like Bruce, who was very warm and affectionate,” Heming Willis continued. “To go in the complete opposite of that was alarming and scary.”
Sawyer, 79, interviewed Dr. Bruce Miller for the special. While Dr. Miller does not treat Willis, he is an expert in FTD, which Sawyer said tends to strike early, as the mean age of when patients are diagnosed is 56 years old.
“This is really the unknown disease. People weren’t aware of it really until the 1990s. The research on this really has just begun,” Dr. Miller explained.
Heming Willis told Sawyer that many patients suffering from FTD often go misdiagnosed as bipolar or suffering from a midlife crisis and depression. It wasn’t until a brain scan that the Pulp Fiction actor was officially diagnosed with what Sawyer referred to as “the black belt” of dementias.
The Make Time Wellness founder was told that there was nothing to be done about Willis’s FTD diagnosis, that there was no cure and no hope.
“To leave there with no … with nothing, just nothing, with a diagnosis I couldn’t pronounce. I didn’t understand what it was,” Heming Willis said. “I was so panicked. And I just remember hearing it and just not hearing anything else. It was like I was free-falling.”
Her experience is what inspired to share her family’s journey in a new book, The Unexpected Journey: Finding Strength, Hope, and Yourself on the Caregiving Path, as a way to throw out a lifeline to loved ones and caregivers who are navigating similar journeys with FTD diagnoses.

Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce are engaged after two years together.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married,” Swift, 35, captioned an Instagram post on Tuesday, August 26, alongside photos of Kelce, also 35, down on one knee.
The couple got engaged in a garden full of flowers and looked happier than ever in a series of images. In addition to the photo of Kelce proposing, the two looked lovingly into each other’s eyes in a second image. Swift also held on to the back of Kelce’s head in one photo, and a fourth had her ring — an old mine brilliant cut designed by Kindred Lubeck at Artifex Fine Jewelry — on full display. The last picture showed Swift sitting with her legs thrown across Kelce’s lap.
The NFL star’s interest in the singer first made headlines in July 2023 after he attempted to give her a friendship bracelet with his phone number during her Kansas City, Missouri, Eras Tour concert. Later that month, he recounted on his “New Heights” podcast how he had failed to meet Swift at the show. She soon reached out to him after hearing the story.
Amid romance rumors, Swift and Kelce went public with their relationship in September 2023 when she attended one of his Kansas City Chiefs home games. She became a fixture in the stands as she cheered him on throughout the season, and he returned the favor when he traveled around the world to watch her perform, with his first visit taking place in Argentina in November 2023.
That same month, Kelce opened up about how he and Swift got together. “There were definitely people she knew that knew who I was, in her corner [who said]: ‘Yo! Did you know he was coming?’ I had somebody playing Cupid,” he told WSJ. Magazine in November 2023. “She told me exactly what was going on and how I got lucky enough to get her to reach out.”
Kelce then addressed how he adjusted to the attention surrounding Swift.
“Obviously I’ve never dated anyone with that kind of aura about them. … I’ve never dealt with it,” he said. “But at the same time, I’m not running away from any of it. … The scrutiny she gets, how much she has a magnifying glass on her, every single day, paparazzi outside her house, outside every restaurant she goes to, after every flight she gets off, and she’s just living, enjoying life. When she acts like that, I better not be the one acting all strange.”
In December 2023, Swift broke her silence on her relationship with Kelce, telling Time that it “started when Travis very adorably put me on blast on his podcast, which I thought was metal as hell.” The two “started hanging out right after that,” according to Swift.
“We actually had a significant amount of time that no one knew, which I’m grateful for, because we got to get to know each other,” she elaborated. “By the time I went to that first game, we were a couple. I think some people think that they saw our first date at that game? We would never be psychotic enough to hard launch a first date.”
While Swift kept some of her past relationships under the radar, she took a different approach with Kelce.
“When you say a relationship is public, that means I’m going to see him do what he loves, we’re showing up for each other, other people are there and we don’t care,” she explained. “The opposite of that is you have to go to an extreme amount of effort to make sure no one knows that you’re seeing someone. And we’re just proud of each other.”
As Swift and Kelce’s romance flourished, a source exclusively told Us Weekly in December 2023 that they’d “had plenty of really deep conversations about their future together” and tried to make “as much time for each other as possible” amid their “incredibly busy schedules.”
More recently, an insider revealed in April that it has “been so refreshing for Taylor not to feel the need to hide with Travis,” adding that he “makes her feel safe and protected like she has the freedom to be and act however she wants.”
Prior to their engagement, Swift had a six-year relationship with Joe Alwyn, while Kelce previously dated Kayla Nicole.

argos_summary: Ellen DeGeneres and her wife Portia de Rossi relocated from Los Angeles to the Cotswolds in late 2024, deciding to stay permanently after Donald Trump’s re‑election. They bought a 43‑acre estate, Kitesbridge Farm, and later listed it for sale, moving to a new home that accommodates de Rossi’s horses and their extensive pet collection. DeGeneres has embraced rural life, enjoying farming, gardening, and the local community, while also reflecting on her career shift and the impact of the 2020 workplace scandal. The couple’s move has been covered in interviews with the BBC, The Wall Street Journal, and various entertainment outlets, highlighting their desire for a simpler, more peaceful lifestyle abroad. Rosie O’Donnell’s own relocation to Ireland is mentioned as a parallel example of celebrities moving overseas for personal and political reasons.
